questions.text: In a complex AC circuit, the "conjugate" of the load impedance is used to calculate the condition for:
A "Butterworth" filter is a type of analog filter known for its:

choices.text: Maximally flat frequency response in the passband.

questions.text: In a BJT, the "beta" ($\beta$ or $h_{fe}$) is temperature-dependent. As temperature increases, $\beta$ generally:
A "Schottky" diode has a very low forward voltage drop and very fast switching speed because it uses a:
An op-amp's "slew rate" is defined as the maximum rate of change of its:
A "Darlington pair" is a compound structure of two bipolar transistors used to provide a very high:
What is a "metastable" state in a flip-flop?

choices.text: An undefined, intermediate state that occurs when setup or hold times are violated.

questions.text: In digital logic design, a "don't care" condition means that for a given input combination:

choices.text: The output can be either '0' or '1', which can be used to simplify the logic.
The input combination will never occur.

questions.text: A "serial adder" is a digital circuit that adds two numbers:

choices.text: All bits at the same time in parallel.
One bit at a time, using a single full adder.

questions.text: In computer architecture, "Amdahl's law" is used to find the:

choices.text: Maximum expected improvement to an overall system when only part of the system is improved.

questions.text: What is a "Non-Maskable Interrupt" (NMI)?

choices.text: An interrupt that can be disabled by the CPU.
A high-priority interrupt that cannot be disabled by the CPU, typically used for critical events like hardware failures.
An interrupt generated by a keyboard.

questions.text: In C, what is the difference between \texttt{const int *p} and \texttt{int * const p}?

choices.text: \texttt{const int *p} is a pointer to a constant integer; \texttt{int * const p} is a constant pointer to an integer.
\texttt{const int *p} is a constant pointer; \texttt{int * const p} points to a constant.

questions.text: In C++, what is "Resource Acquisition Is Initialization" (RAII)?

choices.text: A design idiom that binds resource management (memory, files, sockets) to the lifetime of an object, leveraging the destructor for cleanup.
A way to initialize static variables.

questions.text: What is a "move constructor" in modern C++ used for?

choices.text: To efficiently transfer ownership of resources from a temporary (rvalue) object to another object, avoiding expensive copies.
To move an object in memory.
To construct an object at a specific memory location.

questions.text: What is a "cache coherence protocol" like MESI?

choices.text: A protocol that ensures all caches in a multiprocessor system maintain a consistent view of shared memory.
A protocol for virtual to physical address translation.
A protocol for writing data back to main memory.
A protocol for replacing blocks in a cache.

questions.text: In an RTOS, a "deadline-monotonic" scheduling algorithm assigns priorities based on:

choices.text: The execution time of the task.
The relative deadline of the task (shorter deadline gets higher priority).
The arrival time of the task.

questions.text: What is "TCP meltdown"?

choices.text: A situation where persistent packet retransmissions cause the network to become congested and ultimately unusable.
The process of closing a TCP connection.
A feature of TCP for fast recovery.

questions.text: An "anycast" address in IPv6 is an address that:

choices.text: Identifies a group of interfaces, and a packet sent to it is delivered to only one of the interfaces (the nearest one).
Identifies a group of interfaces, and a packet sent to it is delivered to all of them.

questions.text: A "zero-day" vulnerability is a security flaw that is:

choices.text: Exploited by an attacker on the same day it is discovered by the vendor.

questions.text: A "Turing-complete" system is a system that can:

choices.text: Solve any problem that a Turing machine can solve.

questions.text: In graphics, "Bresenham's line algorithm" is an efficient algorithm for rasterizing a line because it:
The Floyd-Warshall algorithm is used to find the all-pairs shortest paths in a weighted graph and has a time complexity of:
Two-Phase Locking (2PL) is a concurrency control protocol that ensures serializability by:

choices.text: Requiring a transaction to acquire all its locks before releasing any of them.
Creating a snapshot of the database.
Allowing transactions to lock items as needed and release them at any time.

questions.text: The "working set" of a process is the:

choices.text: Entire set of pages used by the process.
Set of pages that the process is currently and actively using.
Set of pages that are in main memory.
Set of pages that have been modified.

questions.text: "Coupling" in software design is the degree of interdependence between modules. Which form of coupling is considered the worst (most undesirable)?
The "Adapter" design pattern is a structural pattern used to:

choices.text: Allow the interface of an existing class to be used as another interface.
Define a communication channel between objects.
Add new responsibilities to an object.

questions.text: "Resolution" is an inference rule used in logic programming and automated theorem proving that is:

choices.text: Used to prove statements by refutation (proving the negation leads to a contradiction).

questions.text: In machine learning, "Gradient Descent" is an optimization algorithm used to:

choices.text: Find the minimum of a function by iteratively moving in the direction of the steepest descent.
Select the best features for a model.

questions.text: The "To-Complete Performance Index" (TCPI) is a project management metric that calculates the:

choices.text: The cost performance that must be achieved on the remaining work to meet a specified management goal.
The total budget of the project.
The final schedule of the project.

questions.text: An engineer's "fiduciary duty" to a client means they have a legal and ethical obligation to:

choices.text: Act in the best interest of the client.
Complete the project at the lowest possible cost.
Share the client's information with other clients.

questions.text: In a BJT, the "beta cutoff frequency" ($f_\beta$) is the frequency at which the common-emitter current gain ($\beta$) drops to:
A "Johnson Counter" of $N$ bits produces a sequence of how many unique states?
In C++, what is a "variadic template"?

choices.text: A template that can take a variable number of template arguments.
A template that can only be used with integer types.
A template that causes a compiler error.

questions.text: What is "Tomasulo's algorithm" used for in CPU design?

choices.text: It's a hardware-based algorithm for dynamic instruction scheduling that allows for out-of-order execution and the use of a common data bus.

questions.text: What is the primary difference between TCP "congestion control" and "flow control"?

choices.text: Flow control prevents the sender from overwhelming the receiver; congestion control prevents the sender from overwhelming the network.
Congestion control prevents the sender from overwhelming the receiver; flow control prevents the sender from overwhelming the network.
Flow control is managed by routers; congestion control by end hosts.

questions.text: A language $L$ is "co-recognizable" if its complement is:
A "skip list" is a probabilistic data structure that allows for fast search within an ordered sequence of elements, with performance comparable to a:
In operating systems, a "spin lock" is a lock where a thread:

choices.text: Blocks and yields the CPU if the lock is unavailable.
Enters a busy-waiting loop, repeatedly checking if the lock has become available.
Is put into a waiting queue.
Is terminated if the lock is unavailable.

questions.text: What is "Domain-Driven Design" (DDD)?

choices.text: A software design approach that focuses on modeling the software to match a domain according to input from domain experts.
A way to design database schemas.
A graphical user interface design methodology.

questions.text: What is the "inference engine" in an expert system?

choices.text: The knowledge base containing facts and rules.
The part of the system that applies logical rules to the knowledge base to deduce new information.

questions.text: An "operational transconductance amplifier" (OTA) is a voltage-controlled:
What is the primary purpose of "clock gating" in digital design?

choices.text: To reduce dynamic power consumption by disabling the clock to inactive parts of the circuit.
To simplify the clock distribution network.

questions.text: In C++, \texttt{reinterpret_cast} is a type casting operator that:

choices.text: Is the safest type of cast.
Is used for converting between pointer types and can be highly dangerous.
Is used for casting away const-ness.
Is used for casting up and down an inheritance hierarchy.

questions.text: What is a "microkernel" operating system architecture?

choices.text: The entire OS runs in a single address space in kernel mode.
Only the most fundamental services (like IPC and basic scheduling) run in the kernel, while other services run in user space.
It is an OS designed for microprocessors only.
It is an older, obsolete architecture.

questions.text: What is the purpose of the "BGP path vector" attribute?

choices.text: To carry a list of Autonomous Systems that a route has traversed, which is used for loop detection.
To determine the bandwidth of a route.
To set the priority of a route.

questions.text: The "CYK algorithm" (Cocke–Younger–Kasami) is a parsing algorithm for:
A "Deadlock" in an OS can be characterized by four necessary conditions, one of which is "Circular Wait". This means:

choices.text: A process is holding at least one resource and waiting for another.
Resources cannot be forcibly taken from a process.
There exists a set of waiting processes $\{P_0, P_1, \dots, P_n\}$ such that $P_0$ is waiting for a resource held by $P_1$, $P_1$ is waiting for $P_2$, \dots, and $P_n$ is waiting for $P_0$.
A resource can only be used by one process at a time.

questions.text: The "Facade" design pattern is a structural pattern that:

choices.text: Provides a simplified, unified interface to a more complex subsystem.
Adds functionality to an object dynamically.
Ensures a class has only one instance.
Allows incompatible interfaces to work together.

questions.text: What is "backpropagation"?

choices.text: An algorithm for training artificial neural networks by propagating the error from the output layer back to the input layer.
A way to query a knowledge base.

questions.text: In project management, what is a "statement of work" (SOW)?

choices.text: A detailed schedule of the project.
A narrative description of the products, services, or results to be delivered by the project.

questions.text: A "clamp" circuit is used to:

choices.text: Add a DC level to an AC signal.
Remove the DC level from a signal.
Limit the amplitude of a signal.

questions.text: What is a "one-hot" encoding?

choices.text: A way of representing categorical data where each category is converted into a binary vector with only one '1' and the rest '0's.
A binary representation of a number.

questions.text: In C, what is the "strict aliasing rule"?

choices.text: A rule that states an object shall have its stored value accessed only by an lvalue expression that has a compatible type, which aids compiler optimization.
A rule about how to name variables.

questions.text: What is "Quality of Service" (QoS) in networking?

choices.text: The process of ensuring that all packets are delivered.
The ability to provide different priority to different applications, users, or data flows, or to guarantee a certain level of performance.
The speed of the network connection.

questions.text: A "LR parser" is a type of bottom-up parser that scans the input from:

choices.text: Left to right, and constructs a rightmost derivation.
Left to right, and constructs a leftmost derivation.
Right to left, and constructs a rightmost derivation.
Right to left, and constructs a leftmost derivation.

questions.text: What is the difference between "unit testing" and "integration testing"?

choices.text: Unit testing tests individual modules in isolation; integration testing tests the interaction between modules.
Unit testing is automated; integration testing is manual.
Unit testing is done by users; integration testing by developers.

questions.text: In machine learning, what does "overfitting" mean?

choices.text: The model is too simple to capture the underlying trend of the data.
The model captures the noise along with the underlying pattern of the training data, leading to poor performance on new data.
The model is trained for too few epochs.
The model has a high bias.

questions.text: The "slack" of a project activity is the amount of time it can be delayed without:
An engineer's ethical obligation to "issue public statements in an objective and truthful manner" prohibits them from:

choices.text: Making exaggerated, misleading, or unsubstantiated claims in professional reports or testimony.

questions.text: What is the difference between a "latch" and a "flip-flop"?

choices.text: A latch is level-triggered, while a flip-flop is edge-triggered.
A flip-flop is level-triggered, while a latch is edge-triggered.
A latch can store more bits than a flip-flop.

questions.text: A Wien bridge oscillator uses a lead-lag network. For the feedback to be purely resistive (zero phase shift), the frequency must be $f = \frac{1}{2\pi R C}$. If $R = 10 \, \mathrm{k}\Omega$ and $C = 1.6 \, \mathrm{nF}$, what is the oscillation frequency?

A Moore machine has four states ($S_0$, $S_1$, $S_2$, $S_3$) with outputs (0, 1, 1, 0) respectively. It transitions from $S_0 \to S_1$, $S_1 \to S_2$, $S_2 \to S_3$, $S_3 \to S_0$ on every input. If the input sequence is 1011, what is the output sequence? (The output is determined by the state).

choices.text: An empty string (or unspecified valid state).

questions.text: A system uses a 4-level page table. If the virtual address is 48 bits and the page size is $4 \, \mathrm{KB}$, and each level of the page table is indexed by the same number of bits, how many bits are used per level?
Consider the RSA algorithm with $p=5$, $q=11$, and $e=7$. What is the private key $d$, and what is the result of decrypting the ciphertext $C=8$?
What is the Liang-Barsky line clipping algorithm's primary advantage over Cohen-Sutherland?

choices.text: It uses more efficient calculations and reduces the number of intersection calculations.

questions.text: A system has 3 processes and 3 resource types. The total resources are (10, 5, 7). The current state is: $P_0$ holds (0,1,0), $P_1$ holds (2,0,0), $P_2$ holds (3,0,2). $P_0$'s max need is (7,5,3), $P_1$'s is (3,2,2), and $P_2$'s is (9,0,2). Is the system safe?

choices.text: Yes, the safe sequence is $\langle P_1, P_0, P_2 \rangle$.
Yes, the safe sequence is $\langle P_1, P_2, P_0 \rangle$.
No, the state is unsafe because $P_2$'s need cannot be met.

questions.text: A project has a BAC of \$200,000. It is 50\% complete according to the plan. The EV is \$80,000, and the AC is \$100,000. What is the Estimate at Completion (EAC) assuming past performance will continue? ($EAC = BAC / CPI$)
Consider a Finite Automaton. How can you determine if it accepts an infinite language?

choices.text: If the number of states is infinite.
If there is a cycle reachable from the start state that can also reach a final state.
If there are more final states than start states.

questions.text: What is the difference between a \texttt{LEFT JOIN} and an \texttt{INNER JOIN} in SQL?

choices.text: \texttt{INNER JOIN} returns all rows from the left table; \texttt{LEFT JOIN} returns only matching rows.
\texttt{LEFT JOIN} returns all rows from the left table and matched rows from the right; \texttt{INNER JOIN} returns only rows where the join condition is met in both tables.

questions.text: The "SOLID" principles are a set of five design principles in object-oriented programming. What does the "D" stand for?
What language does the following grammar represent? $L = \{ S \to aSbb \mid \varepsilon \}$
In TCP, what is the primary purpose of the Nagle algorithm?

choices.text: To reduce the number of small packets sent over the network by buffering data and sending it in larger segments.

questions.text: The problem of "Graph Isomorphism" (determining if two graphs are structurally identical) is a famous problem that is in NP but is not known to be:
In machine learning, "L1 regularization" (like in LASSO regression) has the effect of:

choices.text: Encouraging smaller, but non-zero, model weights.
Encouraging some model weights to become exactly zero, effectively performing feature selection.
Forcing all weights to be positive.

questions.text: In a file system that uses a Free Space Bitmap, a 1 GB disk with a 4 KB block size would require a bitmap of what size? ($1 \, \mathrm{GB} = 2^{30}$, $4 \, \mathrm{KB} = 2^{12}$)
Which design pattern would be used for an object that needs to be created only once per application and needs a global point of access?
A 4-bit binary up-counter is at the state 1011. What will be its state after 3 clock pulses?
What is the primary difference between a "risk" and an "issue" in project management?

choices.text: A risk is a potential future event that may or may not happen; an issue is a current problem that must be addressed.
An issue is a potential future event; a risk is a current problem.
Risks are managed by the project manager; issues are managed by the sponsor.
